However, the explanation of the matter is that if Hashem's intention was only to rectify their encampment places, the journey from place to place could have been accomplished through kefitzat haderech (miraculous shortening of the way) or through the clouds. The Holy One, Blessed be He, would not have troubled them with the journey through the great and awesome desert, for in any case, the journey was miraculous and assisted by the clouds, as our Sages said. If so, the entire journey could have been through the clouds.

But the will and necessity was to rectify and elevate the holy sparks (nitzotzot hakdoshim) along their entire journey route, and the journey itself was an important divine service in its own right. Therefore, it was necessary for their journey to be by foot through the desert path, for if it had been through kefitzat haderech and skipping, they would not have passed through all these places, and the holy sparks there would not have been rectified and elevated.

Therefore, the verse states "they journeyed and encamped" at each journey, and it wasn't sufficient to mention only the encampments, because the journey itself was also a divine service and purpose of rectification just like the encampments. From this, we can explain as Ibn Ezra wrote that when it says "Moses wrote their goings forth according to their journeys by the command of Hashem," it teaches that their journeys were by Hashem's command. This resolves Ramban's question about the redundancy with the earlier verse "by Hashem's command they would camp and by Hashem's command they would journey."

For one might still think that the main purpose was the encampments, and after their encampment place was rectified and they needed another encampment, their journey was by Hashem's command, but the journey was secondary and merely a means to the purpose of the encampments. Therefore, the verse repeats to say "according to their journeys by the command of Hashem," without mentioning the encampments in this verse, to teach that the journeys themselves were an important divine service and by Hashem's command.

Similarly, in this way, the holy tribes recognized from the angels that were created through Yosef's speech that it was all truth and his mouth matched his heart. This is why he said to them "Behold, your eyes see, and the eyes of my brother Binyamin... that it is my mouth speaking to you," for they could see with their eyes Yosef's words, meaning those angels that were created from his speech. From this they discerned that he spoke truth and his mouth matched his heart, and there was no aspect of falsehood or deception in his words, for if there were, it would have been evident in the angels created from his speech.

And regarding what they said that he showed them he was circumcised, one could say that the intention is not simply that he physically showed them his circumcision, but rather the intention refers to the mitzvah of milah (circumcision). He showed them the angels that were created from his mitzvah of milah and that he guarded his covenant, for one who damages his covenant, his foreskin extends. They discerned to know that the mitzvah was complete with him through seeing the holy angels created from his mitzvah of milah.

From this it was clarified to them that he was Yosef HaTzaddik, for such a reality doesn't exist among other people who are not from the seed of Yaakov Avinu, to have the mitzvah of milah in such completeness. It was completely verified to them that he was Yosef, and for this reason the verse repeats to say again "no man stood with him when Yosef made himself known to his brothers," hinting that only man did not stand with him, but those holy angels that were created from his actions and speech of Yosef HaTzaddik stood there.

From them it was verified to the holy tribes that Yosef was their brother, similar to what is written in Yalkut Reuveni (Parshat Vayeshev) that when the attribute of judgment prosecuted the tribes for the sin of selling Yosef, based on what is written "and one who steals a man and sells him, and he is found in his possession, shall surely be put to death," the Holy One Blessed be He responded that it says "steals a man," but Yosef was not a man but rather on the level of an angel. And in this way, the verse hints here "no man stood with him when Yosef made himself known to his brothers," but angels stood there, and through this it was verified to the tribes that he was their brother.

We can explain the verse "to establish for you a remnant in the land, etc." based on what is said in the Gemara regarding ribis (interest) [Bava Metzia 75b]: Those who transgress the negative commandment are the lender, borrower, guarantor, and witnesses. Abaye said the lender transgresses all [prohibitions], etc., while the guarantor and witnesses only transgress "you shall not place upon him interest."

The Gemara [62a] asks: While all others perform an action, what action do the witnesses perform? Rather, is it not that the very act of establishing [the loan] is significant? Thus, even though the guarantor and witnesses didn't perform an actual deed in the matter itself, because the transaction was completed through them, they are liable for the prohibition of "you shall not place," with the root of the action being included in the word "placing."

Similarly, in our matter, Yosef HaTzaddik preceded going to Egypt to prepare a place for Bnei Yisrael so they could maintain their kedushah (holiness) in Egyptian exile, which was the ervat ha'aretz (most defiled land) and extremely contaminated. Through the power of his kedushah and the trials he withstood and overcame, and by becoming ruler over the sar (angel) of Egypt, he weakened the power of tumah (impurity) and klipot (negative forces) at their root.

Through this, Israel merited to be protected from immorality in Egypt - "Bnei Yisrael entered and Bnei Yisrael left" - and not one of them was born from improper relations, as our Sages said. Moreover, Yosef HaTzaddik prepared a power of salvation for future generations until the final exile, so that Israel could overcome and withstand the trials of exile and maintain their kedushah even in the terrible lowliness of ikveta d'meshicha (the footsteps of Mashiach), as the Egyptian exile is the root of all exiles.

The holy Avot and Shevatim were the root of all Jewish souls throughout the generations, and whatever exists in the branch exists in the root. Therefore, through their holy actions, they opened a channel and prepared strength for all generations of Israel. This is the meaning of "to establish for you a remnant in the land and to sustain you for a great deliverance" - that Yosef HaTzaddik established a foundation and root of strength for all generations of Israel. This is the holy spark which is hidden within the nefesh (soul) of every Jew, inherited from our holy forefathers. At first, it is only at the level of a "remnant," but afterward, the boundary of kedushah expands "to sustain you for a great deliverance."

It is written in the holy sefarim that when a tzaddik encounters a rasha (wicked person), he must be very careful not to be spiritually damaged by seeing his face, and only if he has sufficient merits (zechuyot) will he be saved from him. Here, everyone knew that Binyamin was always a complete tzaddik, so how did he suddenly stumble with theft? Therefore, it must either be because he stayed one night in the neighborhood of a rasha, or the entire incident never happened and was merely a false accusation by the ruler.

This is what Yehudah meant when he said, "Is this the 'watching over' that you promised when you said you would keep your eye on him?" Meaning, the theft incident occurred only because of your influence when you set your eyes upon him - this is the meaning of the claim about "setting guilt." In any case, this proves that you do not fear God, so how could you say "I fear God"? Now we know you spoke falsely, and you are like Pharaoh who made you king even though you were a slave, and according to Egyptian law, a slave cannot become king.

This is what is meant by "Just as Pharaoh decrees and doesn't fulfill..." And according to the second interpretation, he said to him, "If you provoke me, I will kill you and your master." This can be understood based on what the Rambam wrote, that the tribes killed the people of Shechem because they didn't establish judges, as Bnei Noach (Noahides) are commanded regarding laws to appoint judges in every district.

Here, since Yosef was viceroy and wanted to keep Binyamin as a slave without justice and with false accusations, Yehudah told him that according to the law, both you and your master deserve death if you do this thing without justice, for you are commanded to execute true justice without wrongdoing.
